Welcome to TEMpcPLOT’s documentation!¶

The library TEMpcPlot has as object the treatments of a Sequence of electropn diffraction cliches to obtain a three dimensional redcipriocal lattice. The idea behind is to find a way of work for TEM, available on pc, with graphycal approach (TEMpcPlot)

The mode of use is relativelly simple :

  1. create a SeqIm object

>>> Ex1 = TEMpcPlot(filelist, angles)

  1. construct a unindixed reciprocal lattice

>>> Ex1.D3_peaks(tollerance=15)

  1. Index manually the reciprocal space

>>> Ex1.EwP.plot()

  1. reconstruct reciprocal space

>>> Ex1.Ewp.create_layer(hkl)
class TEMpcPlot.SeqIm(filenames, filesangle=None, *args, **kwords)¶

sequence of images

this class is supposed to use a sequence of image. each element of the class is an image

Parameters

  • filenames (list) – list string describing the exception.

  • filesangle (str) – Human readable file with angles

EwP¶

Ewald peaks 3D set of peaks

Type

TEMpcPlot.EwaldPeaks

rot_vect¶

list of Rotation vector for each image

Type

list

scale¶

scale(magnification) of the images

Type

list

ima¶

current image of the sequence

Type

TEMpcPlot.Mimage

Note

Methods to use:
def find_peaks(rad_c=1.5, tr_c=0.02, dist=None)
def D3_peaks(stollerance)
def plot(log=False)
D3_peaks(tollerance=15)¶

sum and correct the peaks of all images :param tollerance () = pixel tollerance to determine if a peak: in two images is the same peak.

find_peaks(rad_c=1.5, tr_c=0.02, dist=None)¶

allows to search again the peaks in all the image witht the same parameter :param tr_c: total range coefficent the minimal intensity of the peak should be at list tr_c*self.ima.max() # noqa501 :type tr_c: float :param rad_c: coefficent in respect of the center radious peaks should be separate from at list self.rad*rad_c # noqa501 :type rad_c: float :param dist: (float): maximum distance in pixel

Examples: >>> Exp1.find_peaks()

help()¶

print class help

classmethod load(filename)¶

load a saved project it is necessary that images remain in the same relative position

Parameters

filename (str) – filename to open

Examples

>>> exp1 = SeqIm.load(exp1.pkl)
plot(log=False, *args, **kwds)¶

plot the images of the sequences with peaks

Parameters

  • log (Bool) – plot logaritm of intyensity

  • anf keyworg directly of matplotlib plot (aargs) –

Examples

>>> Exp1.plot(log=True)
>>> Exp1.plot(True)
>>> Exp1.plot(1)
>>> Exp1.plot(0)
>>> Exp1.plot()
save(filesave)¶

save the project to open later formats available: None: pickel format good for python

Parameters

filename (str) – filename to save

Examples

>>> Exp1.save('exp1.pkl')
class TEMpcPlot.EwaldPeaks(positions, intensity)¶

Set of peaks position and intensity

this class manages peaks position and intensity and the methods related to lattice indexing and refinement could be created as an attribute EwP of a SeqIm class by using methods D3_peaks or by sum with an another EwaldPeaks class with the same first image

Example

>>>Exp1.D3_peaks(tollerance=5) >>>EWT= Exp1.EwP + Exp2.EwP

Parameters

  • positions (list) – list containing the coordonates of peaks

  • intensity (list) – list containing the intensity of peaks

pos¶

Ewald peaks 3D set of peaks

Type

list

int¶

list of Rotation vector for each image

Type

list

pos_cal¶

array witht he position in the new basis

Type

np.array

rMT¶

reciprocal metric tensor

Type

np.array

cell¶

a dictionary witht the value of real space cell

Type

dict

calibrate(axes=None, refine=True)¶

given a set of axis reindex the peaks with the new basis

input: axis: the new basis to be used in the format

np.array[[a1, b1, c1],

[a2, b2, c2], [a3, b3, c3]]

if axis is not inoput the programm seach if a new basis has been defined graphically

calculated the attribute: self.pos_cal: array witht he position in the new basis self.rMT : reciprocal metric tensor self.cell : a dictionary witht the value of

real space cell

create_layer(hkl, n, size=0.25, tollerance=0.15, spg=None)¶

create a specific layer create a reciprocal space layer

Parameters

  • hkl (str) – constant index for the hkl plane to plot, format(‘k’)

  • n (float, int) – value of hkl

  • size (float) –

    intensity scaling ::

    • if positive, scale intensity of each peaks respect the max

    • if negative, scale a common value for all peaks

  • tollerance (float) – exclude from the plot peaks at higher distance

  • spg (str) – allows to index the peaks, and check if they are extinted

plot()¶

open a D3plot graph

plot_reduce(tollerance=0.1)¶

plot collapsed reciprocal space

save(filename)¶
formats available:

None: pickel format good for python Idx : for Ind_x

TEMpcPlot.SpaceGroup(SGSymbol)¶

Print the output of SpcGroup in a nicely formatted way.

Parameters

SGSymbol – space group symbol (string) with spaces between axial fields

Returns

nothing

TEMpcPlot.SytSym(XYZ, SGData)¶

Generates the number of equivalent positions and a site symmetry code for a specified coordinate and space group

Parameters

  • XYZ – an array, tuple or list containing 3 elements: x, y & z

  • SGData – from SpcGroup

Returns

a four element tuple:

  • The 1st element is a code for the site symmetry (see GetKNsym)

  • The 2nd element is the site multiplicity

  • Ndup number of overlapping operators

  • dupDir Dict - dictionary of overlapping operators

TEMpcPlot.pt_p(atom, property)¶

Atomic properties.

Returns the selected property for a determined atom

Parameters

  • atom (int, str) – atom by symbol or atomic number

  • property (str) – property type

Returns

property of the atoms

Return type

floats, string

Notes

  • ‘At_w’ : atomic weight

  • ‘Z’ : atomic number

  • ‘cov_r’ : covalent radii

  • ‘sym’ : atomic symbol

  • ‘e_conf’ : electronic conf.

  • ‘ox_st’ : oxydation state

  • ‘bon_dis’ : typical bond distances

  • ‘edges’ : x-ray edges

Examples

>>>pt_p(34, ‘sym’) ‘Se’

>>>pt_p(‘Cu’, ‘At_w’)

63.546
